awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  High-Throughput Direct Ratiometric Calorimeter for Drug Discovery
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the production of the first high-throughput and low-cost Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC) instrument. DSC is an extremely powerful tool for drug discovery that has low adoption due to high costs and low throughput of only one sample every two hours. The power of DSC is the thermodynamic measurements, which do not require any prior specific knowledge of the molecules being studied and do not require any labels. By not requiring any specific knowledge, it is possible to screen a wider variety and a higher quantity of compounds in the search for new drug molecules. The instrument to be developed from this project will be capable of processing 24 to 96 samples every two hours, thereby making DSC-based drug discovery commercially viable. Innovations from this project will also reduce the cost of producing DSC instruments, making them widely accessible for research and educational purposes. An added benefit of the reduced costs is the potential also to be utilized as a teaching tool. The combination of unique drug discovery knowledge and low costs will serve to reduce the costs associated with discovering and analyzing potential new drug molecules.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project comprises the research and development activities required to produce a high-throughput differential scanning calorimeter. A unique feature of the proposed instrument is the utilization of single-use, sterile sample cartridges that can hold 24 to 96 samples. These cartridges will enable high-throughput sample processing compared to currently available instruments. Current instruments use sensors and heaters that are permanently attached to the sample cells. This project will address the technical challenges associated with using non-permanently attached sensors and heaters to enable a sample cartridge that can be inserted and removed from the instrument. Activities of this project will identify optimal materials and components and determine the layout of sample cells to maximize the number of sample cells in each cartridge. These activities will minimize risks associated with producing a production-ready instrument and deliver maximum customer benefit.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) is a powerful and uniquely label-free analytical technique for drug discovery and development activities. Until now, DSC has been underutilized in the market due to the high cost of instruments and the low throughput of only one sample every two hours.  ThermoCap Laboratories has pioneered and patented the first affordable high-throughput calorimeter for drug discovery. The main goal of this project was to convincingly demonstrate functional proof of concept and reduce-to-practice the innovative design features of our DSC instrument. Results of this project attest to the validity for our low-cost, high throughput, DSC instrument for drug discovery applications. 

Intellectual Merit:

DSC instruments can directly measure the heat, a fundamental thermodynamic quantity, associated with interactions in biomolecular systems. Changes in heat provide an extremely sensitive measure of the molecular structure or structural transformations induced by ligand binding, aggregation, and interactions with other molecules. At a most basic level the primary goal of modern drug discovery is to determine how a therapeutic molecule interacts with its target. Therapeutic molecules can be small organic drug molecules or biopharmaceuticals composed of proteins, peptides, lipid, or nucleic acids among others.

A unique quality of DSC is that thermodynamic measurements do not require any prior specific knowledge of the molecules being studied. By not requiring any specific knowledge, it is possible to screen a wider variety and a higher quantity of compounds in the search for new drug molecules earlier in the drug discovery process.

One key feature of our instrument is the disposable and modular sample cartridges. These cartridges are designed to be low-cost, single-use, and most importantly sterile. This removes the need for time-consuming cleaning steps and mitigates the risk of sample contamination while allowing for a wide variety of sample configurations within the instrument.

The market for analytical instrumentation and consumables is large and rapidly growing due to increasing investments in drug development efforts. Currently, these efforts are hampered by expensive, inefficient instrumentation that requires modifications of either the drug candidates or their targets. Our instrument will be the first and only reasonably priced high-throughput instrument capable of label-free analysis of all drug discovery targets from small molecules to biopharmaceuticals.

Broader Impacts:

Our instrument has the potential to have broad societal and economic impacts in three main areas. (1) The economic benefit of a low-cost high-throughput calorimeter is to reduce drug development costs. (2) The economic and societal benefit of bringing modern breakthrough technology to university core laboratories providing exposure of students to state-of-the art next generation instrumentation. Also, with the potential of enhancing collaborative effects between academic and commercial entities. (3) The societal benefit of enabling DSC to be used as an undergraduate tool for teaching thermodynamics. 

Although our product was designed with a primary focus on protein science, drug discovery and development, there are other applications in personalized medicine. Personalized medicine is a rapidly growing field badly in need of more informative tools to generate personalized data sets of individuals. New diagnostic, biometric, and bioinformatic tools are empowering a growth in personalized medicine, where a patient’s unique physiology is used to guide diagnosis and treatment of diseases. There is increased demand in the market for companion diagnostics that consider an individual patients’ health characteristics to determine viability of specific treatment regimes. Our DSC instrumentation will serve a key role in the personalized medicine market. While DSC has proven incapable of differential diagnosis, it is ideally suited for health status monitoring. In essence DSC can act as a minimally invasive “Check Engine Light” for an individual.

 


Last Modified: 02/14/2025
Modified by: Matthew W Eskew

  • Rendering of the ThermoCap DSC shown at scale with a MacBook running our anticipated analysis software.
    ThermoCap Laboratories

    Matthew W Eskew
    ThermoCap DSC
